gasadalur.title: Gasadalur
gasadalur.description: Gasadalur is located on the west-side of Vágar, Faroe Islands, and enjoys a panoramic view over the island of Mykines.

torshavn.title: Tórshavn
torshavn.description: Tórshavn is the capital and largest town of the Faroe Islands.  The Norse established their parliament on the Tinganes peninsula in AD 850. Tórshavn thus became the capital of the Faroe Islands and has remained so ever since.

funningur.title: Funningur
funningur.description: Tradition says that the first viking who settled on the Faroe Islands settled in Funningur. His name was Grímur Kamban, a Norwegian Viking escaping the tyranny of the Norse king Haraldur Hárfagri. However, this is an error in this saga, because Harald's age was in the late 9th century, while the first Norse settlers reached the Faroes after 825.

klaksvik.title: Klaksvík
klaksvik.description: Klaksvík is the second largest town of the Faroe Islands. The town is located on Borðoy, which is one of the northernmost islands. The first settlement at Klaksvík dates back to Viking times.

vioy.title: Viðoy
vioy.description: Viðoy is the northernmost island in the Faroe Islands. The name means wood island, despite the fact that no trees grow on the island.

koltur.title: Koltur
koltur.description: Koltur is an island in the Faroe Islands, located to the west of Streymoy and to the north-west of Hestur. The island has just one settlement, Koltur. It was abandoned in the 1980s by the sheep-farmers whose flocks grazed on the southern part of the island.

mikladalur.title: Mikladalur
mikladalur.description:
"Mikladalur meaning Great-valley is the largest of four villages on the Faroese island of Kalsoy.
Mikladalur has a legend of a selkie/sealwoman. Seals were believed to be former humans who voluntarily sought death in the ocean. Once a year, on Twelfth Night, they were allowed to come on land, strip off their skins and amuse themselves as human beings, dancing and enjoying themselves."

gjogv.title: Gjogv
gjogv.description: Gjógv is a village located on the northeast tip of the island of Eysturoy. The village was named after a 200-metre long sea-filled gorge that runs north to the sea from the village.

kirkjubur.title: Kirkjubøur
kirkjubur.description: Kirkjubøur is the southernmost village on Streymoy, Faroe Islands and the country's most important historical site with the ruins of the Magnus Cathedral from around 1300, the Saint Olav's Church from 12th century and the old farmhouse Kirkjubøargarður from 11th century.

kallurin-kalsoy.title: Kallurin, Kalsoy
kallurin-kalsoy.description: Kalsoy is an island in the north-east of the Faroe Islands between Eysturoy and Kunoy. The name means man island, by contrast with the parallel island to the east, Kunoy, the name of which means woman island. Kalsoy is a comparatively isolated island, in that there are no bridge, tunnel or causeway links to it.

syradalur.title: Syðradalur
syradalur.description: Syðradalur is a small village in the Faroe Islands. It is located on the west coast of Streymoy, in Tórshavn Municipality. Not to be confused with Syðradalur village on Kalsoy, it has a view at the islands Koltur and Vágar.

velbastaur.title: Velbastaður
velbastaur.description: Velbastaður is a village on the island of Streymoy in the Faroe Islands, and is considered among the oldest settlements in the islands.

eiiskollur.title: Eiðiskollur
eiiskollur.description: Eiðiskollur is the 343-meter-high promontory, from the top of which a beautiful view can be had over the sea and the islands.

sandavagur.title: Sandavágur
sandavagur.description: Sandavágur is a city on the south coast of the Faroese island of Vágar. It's the most famous city in the country, and best voted traveling experience. The name Sandavágur means sandy bay and refers to the sandy beach which used to be much larger than present.

slttaratindur.title: Slættaratindur
slttaratindur.description: Slættaratindur is the highest mountain in the Faroe Islands, at an elevation of 880 metres. It is located in the northern part of Eysturoy.  Its name means "flat summit".

beinisvord.title: Beinisvord
beinisvord.description: Beinisvord is a 470 m high sea cliff in Suðuroy, Faroe Islands, the highest sea cliff in Suðuroy. Beinisvørð has vertical cliffs facing the sea and a green slope down towards the village of Sumba.

fugloy.title: Fugloy
fugloy.description: Fugloy is the eastern-most island in the Faroe Islands. The name means bird island, and refers to the large number of birds that nest on the island's cliffs.

sandur.title: Sandur
sandur.description: Sandur is an old site of the thing where every year the local Várting was held. Excavations here have unearthed a stave church from the 11th century, where today there is a typical Faroese wooden church with grass roof. In 1863 while extending the churchyard a treasure of silver was found consisting of 98 coins from the 11th century, half of them of German origin. Furthermore in 1989 archaeologists discovered a pagan burial ground from the times of Viking occupation.

kunoy.title: Kunoy
kunoy.description: Kunoy, meaning Woman island, is an island located in the north-east of the Faroe Islands.

parent.title: Discover Faroe Islands
parent.description:
The Faroe Islands is a self-governing archipelago, part of the Kingdom of Denmark. It comprises 18 rocky, volcanic islands between Iceland and Norway in the North Atlantic Ocean. Hikers and bird-watchers are drawn to the islands’ mountains, valleys and grassy heathland, and steep coastal cliffs that harbor thousands of seabirds.

Imagery collected by Visit Faroe Islands.
